If Bitcoin's future relies on its ability to become a secure settlement layer for a host of technologies, reorgs need to be minimized.

Any reorg deeper than 5 blocks will have serious consequences, especially for layer 2 networks. We're 125 blocks too deep. Time to move on.

1125482332650201089.text:
This is a remarkable next step in the evolution of Bitcoin's base layer.

While some of these changes may seem trivial, they are building blocks for better functionality, efficiency and reliability in Bitcoin. 

Good times

1125482331085705217.text:
6) Tagged hashing for domain separation (avoiding issues like CVE-2012-2459 in Merkle trees).

7) Extensibility through leaf versions, OP_SUCCESS opcodes, and upgradable pubkey types.

1125482330024497153.text:
4) Improvements to the signature hashing algorithm (including signing all input amounts).

5) Replacing OP_CHECKMULTISIG(VERIFY) with OP_CHECKSIGADD, to support batch validation.

1125482329139556352.text:
1) Taproot to make all outputs and cooperative spends indistinguishable from each other.

2) Merkle branches to hide the unexecuted branches in scripts.

3) Schnorr signatures enable wallet software to use key aggregation/thresholds within one input.

1123691238006325249.text:
The Stellar Foundation seems to have fixed the problem for 2 nodes at this time.... but, as it stands, the network can still fail-stop if 3 nodes go down. There's no easy fix.

Big lesson for decentralization and consensus design. Thank you for this research, @yongdaek and team.

1123691232276951041.text:
Unfortunately, both assumptions were wrong. For convenience, users simply selected the Stellar Foundation for their quorum when joining the network, and that put a lot of trust on a very small number of nodes. 

The result is a highly centralized topology:pic.twitter.com/4qLOMoOnYV

1123691231463321601.text:
For context, the Stellar Consensus Protocol (SCP) allows users to select which entities they trust. 

It's an interesting scheme if your assumptions are that 1) there will be enough users running nodes in the network and 2) users care enough about quorum decentralization.

1123691230490189824.text:

1119319900949024770.text: 9\ In essence, this is Binance trying to control the entire supply chain of tokens.

1119319900110106625.text: 8\ The rise of IEOs also shouldn't be surprising. Speculation continues to be the main use case for tokens, and this is an example of a secondary market (Binance) vertically integrating the primary market (Ethereum), where tokens are issued.

1119319899363586051.text: 7\ While the intended use-case for BinanceChain is a DEX, I would characterize it as a DEX-ish, given its dependence on a centralized counterpart for liquidity, and its reliance on a centralized validation quorum.

1119319898474283008.text:
6\ The EVM will be necessary for Binance to successfully push its IEO strategy.

While this can abstract value from token issuance and trading on Ethereum, maybe it's exactly what it needs at this point to prove its worth beyond speculation.

1119319897538998278.text:
5\ There is a lot of confusion around what BinanceChain *actually* is. 

TL;DL: it's a network built with the Cosmos-SDK running on a centralized Tendermint-based DPoS. 

What this means is that it's trivial to add an EVM module to it, and execute anything based on Ethereum.

1119319896771444737.text: 4\ The timing for BinanceChain is particularly good, since a lot of these tokens failed to deliver on 2017 promises and are grasping for relevance (or at the very least a partnership-announcement-pump). Many tokens are now in line to get the "migration pump" or an IEO.

1119319895777468417.text: 3\ Given that the only "utility" of most Ethereum tokens at this point is as a medium of exchange, they would surely be better-off (especially when it comes to liquidity) by migrating to a centralized chain associated with a centralized exchange.

1119319894821101568.text: 2\ Binance has been successful because they were able to capitalize on (1) continuous speculative demand for tokens, (2) a shift in the regulatory landscape in China, (3) the issuance of a token that simulates (the illusion of) scarcity, and (4) an incredibly competent team.

1119319893864800257.text:
1\ I wouldn't be surprised if, in ~2 years, Binance were to become Ethereum's equivalent to Bitmain; a massive, centralized, self-serving agent that retains a lot of power.

1105912890870108160.text: 11\ Ultimately, the long-term demand for privacy through these types of transaction directly translates into an increase in on-chain transaction fees. As such, demand for privacy can be an instrumental way to develop Bitcoin's fee market after the last bitcoin has been mined.

1105912890035453958.text: 10\ In conjunction techniques such as Pay-to-EndPoint (P2EP), Schnorr can enable the creation of new transactions types that break the heuristics widely used in blockchain analysis, and make it nearly impossible to pin point specific entities by simply looking at the blockchain.

1105912889301450753.text: 9\ These features will address some of the shortcomings of CoinJoin, a privacy-preserving technique where multiple senders and receivers are combined within a single transaction. CoinJoin transactions are larger in size, but with Schnorr, they will offer much better privacy.

1105912888521297921.text: 8\ In this article, I describe some interesting features of Schnorr-based signatures, including key aggregation, private off-chain smart contracts and the potential for cross-input aggregation.

1105912887745433600.text: 7\ But what if I told you Schnorr may be the first step toward *sufficient privacy* through techniques that do not require hard-forks or otherwise compromise auditability?

1105912886981988353.text:
6\ Similarly, inflation bugs and double spends become harder to identify, and the requirement of trusted setups for some schemes pose considerable risks. 

Thus, a push for the implementation of cutting-edge privacy on Bitcoin’s base layer will likely divide its community.

1105912886210252800.text: 5\ Apart from the requirement of a HF, a problem with these technologies is that they can prevent the full audibility of Bitcoin’s monetary base. In other words, when transaction values are encoded, it becomes difficult to verify whether Bitcoin’s supply cap is, in fact, 21M BTC.

1105912884536717318.text:
4\ We now have novel privacy-preserving technologies that are evolving at a fast pace, including Confidential Transactions, Bulletproofs, zkSNARKs, zkSTARKs, and MimbleWimble.

But I don't think any of them will ever be implemented on Bitcoin.

1105912883811106817.text:
3\ As such, Bitcoin's privacy guarantees and its long-term sustainability without perpetual inflation are perhaps two of the most divisive issues surrounding Bitcoin today. 

And while very different in nature, there's a chance they will be solved simultaneously.

1105912883018432513.text: 2\ At the same time, the popularity of the Lightning Network and its own potential to host private payments has generated uncertainty about future demand for on-chain settlement and the security of the network when there are no more block rewards.

1105912882070540288.text: 1\ It is reasonable to assume that Bitcoin’s long-term adoption depends upon the strength of its privacy guarantees, and that the proliferation of blockchain analysis can be a threat.

1053296883970523136.text: 14\ An interesting observation for the cryptography nerd: once Bulletproofs activate, Monero and Zcash will become cousins. Both make use of Non-Interactive Zero Knowledge Proofs that conceptually share a common ancestor: the Fiat-Shamir heuristic. Maybe now we can stop fighting?

1053296882880053253.text: 13\ The space savings granted by Bulletproofs may also enable the implementation of additional obfuscation mechanisms. As I have suggested to MRL, increasing the mandatory number of outputs in a transaction can make it significantly harder to trace balances by analyzing the chain

1053296881621712896.text: 12\ This is a significant increase in efficiency, as it reduces transaction size and lowers fees. Bitcoin can greatly benefit from Monero's testing of Bulletproofs (& CT), and it's great to see developers applying this technology to a network of Monero's size.

1053296880355024896.text:
11\ Up until today, XMR transactions scaled mostly linearly depending on the number of outputs (ex: 1 output = 7kB, 2 outputs = 14kB). 

Now, under Bulletproofs, transaction size will scale logarithmically (ex: 1 output = 2kB, 2 outputs = 2.5kB).

1053296879432359937.text: 10\ Relative to zk-SNARKs, the NIZKP system proposed by the Bulletproof white paper has both benefits and drawbacks. On one hand, it does not require a trusted setup for parameter generation, like Zcash. On the other hand, its verification is more time consuming.

1053296878459277312.text: 9\ For context, the basic concept behind a NIZKP is to cryptographically prove that something exists, without knowing what that something is. This is achieved by issuing a set of challenges that, if completed successfully, can statically prove that a party has a secret.

1053296877658169349.text: 8\ Range proofs consume a lot of space, and this is the problem Bulletproofs can address. It proposes using a non-interactive zero knowledge proof (NIZKP) system to aggregate all the range proofs of a Confidential Transaction and collectively prove their validity.

1053296876798332928.text: 7\ All input values in an XMR transaction are encoded, and a by-product of this process is a data point called a range proof. In essence, range proofs allow the network to verify that the amounts in a tx are not negative, and that the sender is not creating XMR out of thin air.

1053296875237990400.text: 6\ At a low level, the fundamental basis of Confidential Transactions is a cryptographic primitive for encoding called a Pedersen commitment. For context, cryptographic primitives are the building blocks of systems that use cryptography and are comprised of well-known algorithms.

1053296874436939776.text: 5\ RingCT adds Confidential Transactions to this scheme, which hide transaction amounts. Despite popular belief, Confidential Transactions use encoding (which keeps data hidden, immutable and verifiable), instead of encryption (which keeps data hidden and reversible).

1053296871224078336.text: 4\ Monero uses a Ring Signature scheme, whereby a transaction's real sender is mixed with decoy signatures pulled from the chain. The primary goal of a ring signature is to enable the true signer of a message to claim plausible deniability, as real & decoy signers become equal.pic.twitter.com/qpV2RKrynh

1053296870334832640.text:

1027994858546507776.text: Otherwise, one party may receive her share of the swap before the other and that creates asymmetric risk. The Lightning Network uses Hash Time-Lock Contracts (HTLCs), a type of sMarT cOntRact that can be used for off-chain atomic swaps.

1027994857271382016.text: The common denominator in all approaches is ATOMICITY. The term atomic comes from its original Greek meaning “uncuttable,” and used to name the Atom (initially thought to be indivisible). Atomic swaps must be indivisible: either ALL transactions happen at once, or none.

1027994856302542850.text: Interoperability is an umbrella term. It involves *atomically* moving assets from chain A to chain B. Generally speaking, there are 3 ways to achieve this: 1 - sidechains (Liquid), 2 - on/off-chain atomic swaps (LN), 3 - intermediary network (Cosmos, etc)https://twitter.com/Melt_Dem/status/1027942661343330305 …

1008124570128314369.text: The trade-offs between decentralization and scalability can be a double-edged sword. There is a simple reason why #Bitcoin has been functional 99.99% of the time: it's truly decentralized. Very different model, but my point is that 21 nodes might not be enough for liveliness atm.

1008124568932880384.text: The Delegated Proof-of-Stake Consensus schema developed for BitShares is very different than the one used in EOS, which has barely been tested. 1004814498404995073.text: So why are some interoperability projects spending so much of their ICO proceeds on hype, marketing, and "building a community" when the end user will most likely be a developer? DGMW, building a community of developers is important, but how many TCP meetups do you know?

1004814497205374978.text:
Sounds good, right? But let's take a step back. How many internet users today know what DNS, TCP, FTP, or UDP even are? Probably very few. 
Why? Because these protocols are meaningless to end user. And the same will most likely happen to interoperability protocols.

1004814496353935360.text: The market also benefits in this world because developers will have to chose between between privacy ‘services’ such as $XMR, vs. $ZEC, vs. $DASH for the payments within the platform, which ultimately increases market efficiency.

1004814495431131137.text: This way, Dapp developers can focus on the core offering of their platform, rather than having to create all of these different features internally, which would take a long time and most likely require extensive expertise and effort.

1004814494407815168.text: But soon, developers will be able to ‘outsource’ key features of their Dapps like payments, governance and identity. Interoperability could enable the decentralized version of Uber, for example, to offer its users payments via $ZEC, governance via #Aragon, and identity via #uPort

1004814492847558658.text: The crypto landscape today is made up of hundreds of siloed networks that are not good at exchanging information, and this creates inefficiencies. If I'm developing a Dapp and have to bootstap every single feature that I want it to have, odds are my dapp won't be great.

998669564811628545.text: 7\ Lastly, the Avalanche protocol uses a dynamic Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) to query the genealogy of the UTXO’s consumed in the transactions that are being validated.

998669425233588226.text: 6\ The next protocol, Snowball, augments conviction by reiterating the decisions made by each validator multiple times. These are the 'confidence counters' referred in the white paper.

998669148237508609.text: 5\ Then, the Snowflake protocol, which is Byzantine fault tolerant, augments the decisions made through Slush by checking the strength of a node’s conviction in its current validating set.

998669029962387458.text: 4\ Under the hood, four distinct sub-protocols operate under the same metastable mechanism. Consensus begins with Slush, a simple algorithm inspired by gossip protocols that are widely used to disseminate information in distributed systems. Slush determines the consensus quorums.

998668876689936384.text: 3\ The interesting aspect of the protocol is that consensus is reached by a random set of validators, which is probabilistic (like in Nakamoto consensus), but these validators still engage in a series of voting rounds (like in classical consensus).

998668748465860609.text: 2\ “Snowflake to Avalanche” is a metastable protocol, meaning, it will ultimately reach equilibrium on the ratio of agreements and disagreements in the network after the consensus process.https://twitter.com/LucasNuzzi/status/998668584300707842 …
